summary: This document is a chain of emails from August 10, 2019, concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It shows frantic communication between a U.S. Attorney's Office prosecutor and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the correctional center, with the prosecutor urgently requesting basic facts (time and cause of death) to relay to Epstein's defense counsel, while the correctional staff provide minimal initial updates.

persons.name: Supervisory Staff Attorney CLC
persons.role: Supervisory Staff Attorney at the Metropolitan Correctional Center
persons.context: The sender of the main email, attaching a press release about Epstein's death and stating they will be inside the institution and out of touch.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: Mentioned as a contact for urgent matters in an automatic out-of-office reply from a prosecutor who is on vacation.

connections.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney is communicating with the U.S. Attorney's Office (which includes the AUSA) regarding updates on Epstein's death.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is reported to have 'passed away' at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, following an earlier report of him being taken to the hospital from 'another apparent suicide attempt'.

events.title: Epstein taken to hospital
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) informs the U.S. Attorney's Office that Epstein is being taken by ambulance to the hospital from 'another apparent suicide attempt'.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The email chain documents the immediate aftermath and official communication regarding Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.

A prosecutor from the U.S. Attorney's Office expresses extreme frustration at receiving less information than the press and urgently needs basic facts (time and cause of death) to provide to Epstein's defense counsel.
Initial BOP updates refer to Epstein's situation as 'another apparent suicide attempt' before confirming his death.
A Supervisory Staff Attorney at the MCC is at the institution, attaches a press release, and will be out of contact while inside.
The correspondence highlights the information vacuum and operational confusion between the correctional facility, the BOP, and the prosecuting office following Epstein's death.
